H0.text: Wind is the natural factor whose effect on the landscape is demonstrated by a student using a fan and a box of sand to model the formation of sand dunes.

H1.text: Water is the natural factor whose effect on the landscape is demonstrated by the student's model, which uses a fan and a box of sand to simulate the formation of sand dunes.

H2.text: Temperature is the natural factor whose effect on the landscape is demonstrated by a student who uses a fan and a box of sand to model the formation of sand dunes.

H3.text: Gravity is the natural factor whose effect on the landscape is illustrated by a student who uses a fan and a box of sand to model the formation of sand dunes.

A6.text: Wind-blown sand moves up the gentle upwind side of the dune by saltation or creep.

A7.text: The state of an aeolian system depends mainly on three things: The amount of sediment supply, the availability of sediments, and the transport capacity of the winds.
